ygData.subject: Re: [archive-crawler] 3rd crash (segfault) with 1.14.3 on a large crawl with large seed list
ygData.msgSnippet: I ll answer this on a few levels. Providing the exact error you received helps a lot, thank you for that. The nutshell answer: use ulimit -n to allow the JVM

I'll answer this on a few levels. Providing the exact error you received 
helps a lot, thank you for that.

The nutshell answer: use 'ulimit -n' to allow the JVM process to have 
more open files and the crash will probably go away. If you can upgrade 
to Java 5 update 19, or Java 6 update 14 (when available), that should 
address the underlying Java JVM bug.

I have some other comments on your crawl setup -- but as they're not 
related to the crash I'm going to put them in a separate message.

The longer answer -- how to diagnose these issues:

Every JVM crash is a serious platform bug; no pure Java code (and we in 
Heritrix don't call out to our own native libraries) should be killing 
the process with a SIGSEGV memory error, because all memory-addressing 
is supposed to be handled cleanly by Java. (At worst, if you ask for 
more memory than available, we should get an OutOfMemoryError.)

So at this level, something's very wrong here, but it may be only 
tangentially related to Heritrix.

Composing the right Google query to find out if a problem has been 
encountered and fixed before is a bit of an art, but I find things like 
error type, symbolic parts of the error message (as opposed to 
arbitrarily-different counters/addresses), and transitions between 
layers (as between core Java classes/methods and implementation 
specifics, or from the Java stack to the native stack, etc.) to be most 
interesting.

In the error message the terms/lines that stick out to me are:

SIGSEGV
     (the type of error)

~BufferBlob::jni_fast_GetIntField
     (the last native frame before the crash)

sun.nio.ch.FileDispatcher.preClose0(Ljava/io/FileDescriptor;)V+0
     (the last java frame before JVM goes into a native method)

sun.nio.ch.DatagramChannelImpl.finalize()V+1
     (somewhat more subtly, a java frame that includes both a 
recognizable user-level facility -- Datagrams, as per UDP sockets -- and 
a hairy common GC-linked operation -- object finalization)

Picking any mix of these would be good choices to try as a Google query; 
I went with [SIGSEGV jni_fast_GetIntField] and got results pointing to 
the relevant JVM bug report at Sun (#1) *and* a previous Heritrix bug 
report discussing the bug and workarounds (#3).

For the JVM bug (#6497734), Sun reports the following "Release Fixed" 
information:

7(b06), 5.0u17-rev(b11) (Bug ID:2171990) , 6u14(b03) (Bug ID:2171991) , 
5.0u19(b01) (Bug ID:2174427)

Decoding Sun release numbers can be a challenge but I gather from the 
above this bug is fixed in:

Java 5 update 19 (and maybe some variant of u17) -- available at:
http://java.sun.com/javase/downloads/index_jdk5.jsp

Java 6 update 14 -- which is not yet officially released but can be 
retrieved via early access at:
https://jdk6.dev.java.net/6uNea.html

Java 7 as of 'b06' -- not yet officially release, but b59 is available 
via early access at:
http://download.java.net/jdk7/binaries/

So if you can upgrade your Java to one of those, the problem is likely 
to go away.

 From the Heritrix issue (<http://webarchive.jira.com/browse/HER-1126>), 
it also seems that ensuring the system allows processes plenty of open 
files (via 'ulimit -n') avoids the crashes. This workaround has worked 
for us at the Internet Archive; we are not yet to Java 5u19 or 6u14 on 
our production crawls.

- Gordon @ IA
